dc:description:
*RAI1* was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant Smith-Magenis syndrome in 2003 (Slager et al., PMID: 12652298). A microdeletion overlapping multiple genes in chromosome 17p11.2 was first identified in individuals with Smith-Magenis syndrome, and subsequent studies indicated that haploinsufficiency of *RAI1* within the deleted region is responsible for most of the clinical manifestations. Affected individuals exhibit intellectual disability, delayed speech, dysmorphic facial features, sleep disturbances, and behavioral disorders, including autism.

Nine variants (missense, nonsense, and frameshift) that have been reported in nine probands in four publications (PMIDs: 15565467, 15788730, 17041942, 12652298) are included in this curation. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 points) has been reached. To date, 32 unique variants within *RAI1* have been classified as pathogenic in ClinVar. The mechanism of pathogenicity is known to be loss of function.

This gene-disease relationship is also supported by mouse models and patient-derived cells. The experimental evidence collectively shows that *RAI1* is critical for cognitive function (intellectual disability), craniofacial development (dysmorphic facial features), energy homeostasis (obesity), and circadian rhythm (sleep disturbances).

In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between *RAI1* and autosomal dominant Smith-Magenis syndrome. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Intellectual Disability and Autism Gene Curation Expert Panel on September 5, 2018 (SOP Version 5).

The RAI1 gene has been associated with Smith-Magenis syndrome using the ClinGen Validity Framework as of 9/3/2018. The affected individuals show intellectual disability, delayed speech, dysmorphic facial features, sleep disturbances, and behavioral problems. This disease association was made using case-level data and experimental data. At least 9 variants (missense, nonsense, and frameshift) were curated from four publications (PMID: 15565467, 17041942, 15788730, and 12652298). More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached. While a micro-deletion in short arm of chromosome 17 was first identified in individuals with Smith-Magenis syndrome, subsequent studies indicated that haploinsufficiency of RAI1 within the deletion region is responsible for most of the clinical manifestations. To date, 32 unique variants within RAI1 have been classified as Pathogenic in ClinVar. The gene-disease association is supported by mouse models and patient-derived cells. The experimental evidence collectively shows that RAI1 is critical for cognitive function (intellectual disability), craniofacial development (dysmorphic facial features), energy homeostasis (obesity), and circadian rhythm (sleep disturbances). In summary, RAI1 is definitively associated with Smith-Magenis syndrome. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time.

evidence.dc:description: Only assess circadian genes dysregulation in patient fibroblast but not other neurological phenotypes.

The study shows that transcript levels of all assessed circadian genes (RAI1, CLOCK, PER1, ARNTL2, NR1D1, and CRY1) in patient fibroblast are dysregulated when compared to those of normal fibroblasts.
evidence.rdfs:label: Circadian gene dysregulation in SMS patient fibroblasts

evidence.dc:description: The mouse model partially recapitulates SMS patient phenotypes, that are obesity and craniofacial abnormalities.

SMS patients are often overweight. Significant weight differences began to be observed at 20 weeks of age in the heterozygous males and 23 weeks in females. Both sexes of Rai1+/− animals were overweight compared with littermate controls.
evidence.rdfs:label: Recapitulate obesity and craniofacial abnormalities in mouse

evidence.dc:description: Heterozygous knockout mice manifest circadian rhythm abnormalities in the molecular level, which may explain sleep disturbance in SMS patients. The circadian rhythms abnormalities in heterozygous knockout mice were previously documented in another paper (PMID: 23703963) by challenging these mice with 12hr/12hr Dark/Dark cycle after acclimation to standard 12hr/12hr Light/Dark cycle.

Haploinsufficiency of RAI1 results in Smith-Magenis syndrome (SMS), a disorder characterized by intellectual disability, multiple congenital anomalies, obesity, neurobehavioral abnormalities, and a disrupted circadian sleep-wake pattern. Expression analysis of Rai1 and Clock in the Rai1+/− mouse hypothalamus during the light phase showed reduced expression of both genes. The expression of downstream targets of Clock and other essential components of the circadian feedback loop, including Per2, Npas2, and Nr1d2, had reduced expression These data illustrate dysregulation of diurnal gene expression in the Rai1+/− mouse hypothalamus.
evidence.rdfs:label: Circadian rhythm dysregulation in heterozygous mouse

evidence.dc:description: The conditional knockout of Rai1 in different neuronal subtypes in this study shows that gene is critical for learning (intellectual disability), energy homeostasis (obesity), and motor skill development (delayed motor developmental milestone). However, except for obesity, the learning deficit and motor function deficits are not obvious in heterozygous knockout mice (PMID: 17517686)

Haploinsufficiency of Retinoic Acid Induced 1 (RAI1) causes Smith-Magenis syndrome (SMS), which is associated with diverse neurodevelopmental and behavioral symptoms as well as obesity. Behavioral analyses demonstrated that pan-neural loss of Rai1 causes deficits in motor function, learning, and food intake. These SMS-like phenotypes are produced by loss of Rai1 function in distinct neuronal types: Rai1 loss in inhibitory neurons or subcortical glutamatergic neurons causes learning deficits, while Rai1 loss in Sim1+ or SF1+ cells causes obesity.
evidence.rdfs:label: Recapitulate motor function, learning deficits, and obesity
Patient BAB1106
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Negative for FISH study of 17p11.2 deletion.

evidence.dc:description: The variant was not seen in her mother, while father was not available (sperm donor) for testing.

evidence.rdfs:label: SMS153
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Negative for Fragile X testing. Normal karyotyping, Negative for FISH study of 17p11.2 deletion and 22q11.2 deletion.

evidence.dc:description: The score was downgraded for the missense variant, which was reported to be de novo by the study without supporting evidence. The functional alternation of this missense variant was reported in another study (PMID: 22578325), which shows that patient derived fibroblast cell line manifests dysregulation of key circadian genes, given that sleep disturbance is a well-characterized feature of SMS patients.

evidence.rdfs:label: SMS175
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Normal karyotyping. Negative for FISH study of 17q11.2 deletion.

evidence.dc:description: The variant is a de novo 29bp deletion, resulting in frameshifting mutation.

evidence.rdfs:label: SMS129
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: broad, square face, self hugging, onychotillomania, polyembolokoilamania, hand biting, attention seeking
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Negative for Fragile X. Normal chromosome analysis.

evidence.dc:description: This is a de novo one nucleotide insertion, resulting in frameshifting mutation.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient BAB1852
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Negative for FISH study of 17p11.2 deletion.

evidence.dc:description: This variant is a single nucleotide deletion, resulting in frameshifting mutation.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: onychotillomania, polyembolokoilamania, self hugging, broad, square face, brachydactyly, hand biting, hearing loss
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Negative for Fragile X and FISH studies for deletion 17p11.2

evidence.dc:description: This is a single nucleotide deletion, resulting in frameshifting mutation. The score was downgraded because the variant was mentioned to be de novo by the study without supporting data.

evidence.previousTestingDescription: Normal karyotyping. Negative for Fragile X and FISH study for 17p11.2 deletion.

evidence.dc:description: This de novo variant is a single nucleotide deletion, resulting in frameshifting mutation.
